cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 153 (Friday, October 4, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. PEREZ:H.R. 9935.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I of the U.S. ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:Taxes[Page H5854]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

cdata.text:
Lowering Energy Costs for Manufactured Homeowners Act

This bill provides a new refundable tax credit in the amount of 20% of the cost of manufactured home skirting, up to a maximum amount of $500. Home skirting is any weather-resistant material used to enclose the space between the bottom of the manufactured home and the ground. The tax credit is not available for taxpayers whose modified adjusted gross income exceeds $150,000 (or $300,000 for joint filers). Finally, the manufactured home must be used as the taxpayerâ€™s primary residence.

bill.title: Lowering Energy Costs for Manufactured Homeowners Act

item.title: Lowering Energy Costs for Manufactured Homeowners Act
Lowering Energy Costs for Manufactured Homeowners Act
To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to establish a refundable tax credit for the addition of skirting to certain manufactured homes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
